pros: -Working in the online program is convenient and once you've taught a class a few times and develop a work flow the lesson planning is less time consuming. -Pay is competitive -A lot of autonomy
cons: -Some students can be difficult and treat the instructor/student relationship more like a customer service relationship -Some course coordinators are too concerned about their course's reputation and will ask you to inflate grades to make the course easier, taking away the integrity of the program -In the online program they do try but it's hard to feel connected to your team and fellow instructors -Too many of the policies are vague and open to interpretation

pros: Have some flexibility but depends on the functions.
cons: DU is top heavy, some senior leaders have been here for 30+ years and reluctant to change. They always wanted to hire the best from outside DU, and those outside hires don't like how this place operates and all left in a short period of time. Yet, DU won't give internal people much opportunities unless they really like you. And it is always the same group of people on the so called search committees and make decisions. If you are a minority that looks different and talks different, your opportunity to advance is next to zero no matter how good a job you have done. Also, male colleagues typically makes more than female colleagues. You need to know how to play the game of favoritism, otherwise a manager of people will end up with making less than an individual contributor even if you both are in the same pay grade with the same title. When it's merit time, performance review doesn't mean anything, you will end up with a below average raise with a solid performance if you are not the favorite one.

review_title: The Research Centers can be toxic work environments
pros: Decent pay and benefits. The people who aren't senior management are kind and want each other to succeed. Too bad you will not work with any of them for more than a year before most leave, or have now taken on so many other people's work that they cannot possibly spend any time talking about things other than work.
cons: You will work 60+ hours a week, every week. If complain about that, you will be told to get over it and have the interesting projects you enjoy shuttered while having the most menial and unsatisfying work dumped on you with no warning. There is no project management system and it takes six-plus months for essential roles to be filled. Everyone then ends up taking on two to four other people's jobs and will do work wildly outside their job description. Their idea of "building a career" for somebody is just dumping more work on them, with no extra pay or benefits. But since they have made it so now you are handling three people's jobs instead of two, they will be shocked that you didn't consider working 80+ hours a week a reward for your good work.

pros: Tuition reimbursement benefits for employees
cons: DU has become a sinking ship. With serious turnover and retention issues leadership should be turning their heads to how they can retain the talent that is left. Burnout is a serious concern if you take a role at the University as teams are understaffed. Do not expect strong compensation when working here. There is a strong disconnect between staff and faculty, and faculty are not held to the same standards as staff. Leadership is typically not strong within departments and there is little leadership that is visible from the top of the organization. Even when they are visible they are not focusing on the correct priorities. It seems leadership believe a free lunch every once in a while is enough to keep employees satisfied. There is a toxic culture that has been instilled since returning to campus post-COVID that leadership is neglecting to address.

pros: I work in one of the biology/chemistry laboratories. Overall, the lab culture seems is very chill. I see some cross-lab discussion and collaboration, but (this may be the pandemic talking) people seem to keep to themselves. I hear about gossip occasionally from my PI and it's not insane. Normal university stuff. Pay is good for university work, but not enough to live comfortably in Denver on a single salary. Benefits are nice.
cons:
Pay could be higher. Also, a ton of the laboratories seem to be making do with out-of-date technologies. There are machines in my laboratory older than me (they're not used, but they are there). I get the sense that many of the labs lack the will or the funding to get into newer types of sequencing and analysis.
Also, DU really wants to be inclusive, but I think it struggles due to the fact that it is a private university. It does make it a priority though.

review_title: Good experience working with Student Life in the Student Outreach & Support Offices (SOS)
pros: Being a case manager at Student Outreach & Support (SOS) allowed me to work with a great, fun, and committed staff that had a good team vibe. The supervisors were very supportive and recognized the importance of taking time for yourself if needed. The University of Denver (DU) also has many resources which made the work easier. Supporting students with all of DU's resources at my disposal made me feel effective at my job and really gave the students so many more opportunities.
cons: The job had a low pay, especially as a graduate student employee versus a full-time or salaried employee. This was difficult because the case loads were very large and we were always busy. The office is working on ways to create more staff positions and design more consistency protocols to improve this situation. Also, a lot of the case managers left this year because they either graduated or for personal reasons unrelated to the work. This means that the staff is going to have to rebuild next year, which may mean the team dynamic will be much different. Honestly, there aren't a lot of cons as long as you enjoy case management. If you are looking at this job as a form of professional development, just know that you will have to take the initiative to ask for, create, and find those professional development opportunities because sometimes the job gets so busy that you get stuck just case managing for awhile (which of course is still a good skill to build).

review_title: Try not to hit your head on the glass ceiling
pros: Generally the people working at DU are nice. The University matches retirement contributions up to 4% and benefitted employees are eligible for tuition waiver (20 credits per academic year) after 6 months (after 7 years service, dependents receive 90% tuition waiver). If you want to work in the same job for years/decades on end with little to no prospect of advancement, DU is perfect for you. If you want to get a(nother) degree and have a few years to spare, DU is a great option.
cons: If you're hoping to get your foot in the door and move up, do not waste your time with DU. The university is extremely flat as an organization, HR knows about it, but does not care. Salaries are pitifully low. Most posted jobs are in the mid-30s. Hiring culture at DU is horrendous and there is almost no desire to leverage motivated, qualified internal candidates. The trend is, and continues to be to hire outside the university despite over-qualified, internal candidates. Internal transfers only seem to occur through cronyism and not through actual merit, experience, or what is best for the university or a given position.

pros: Tuition reimbursement, and some of the people there are excellent. Lots of opportunities for professional and intellectual engagement. Working on a campus can be energizing and a lot of fun. Cheap membership to the gym on campus. RTD pass.
cons:
They pay a lot of lip service to diversity efforts, but fail to deliver. 

Very elitist attitude from administration. It's ridiculous how into appearances and perceptions they are; appearance matters more than genuine change.  

A lot of kingdom building in different areas around the university. There's a level of politics there that I've never experienced before. It can get very nasty. Very siloed as far as communication and interdepartmental collaboration goes.  I ended up leaving because the silos combined with the cutthroat politics just got too stressful. 

Parking is a nightmare and employees have to pay - when you first start, expect to be on a waiting list for at least a year to get into a decent parking lot. You'll likely be stuck in a lot that's nowhere near where you actually work for 1-2 years. Not a lot of options if you don't make a lot and want a lower cost option.

review_title: Talks the talk, doesn't walk the walk
pros:
-The staff and students are amazing! 
-The benefits are wonderful (health, matching 401k after 12 months of full-time work)
-Great place to work for those with small children
-Beautiful campus
-Dedicated to making students and staff feel safe on campus
cons:
-The salaries are quite low, often $10k less than other higher education institutions
-No salary increases to coincide with the cost of living
-High elimination of positions resulting in one person doing several jobs without compensation 
-Does not value feedback from staff on how to things can be improved; rather, the organization puts the burden on improvement back on the staff
-The faculty is often abusive to the staff (in my personal experience, this was 60% of faculty)
-There is little to no support from upper management
-Uses minority students, staff, and faculty members as a token to show how diverse the university is, but this is a misrepresentation of the campus environment
-Several ongoing lawsuits regarding discrimination, favoritism, and hostile work environments 
-Faculty and upper management has a "us vs. them" mentality when they think about staff

pros:
Great work/life balance and schedule flexibility.  It's a pretty rare day that I have to work late.  There seems to be a genuine understanding that people have lives outside of work. 

The people, at least in my department, are awesome.  DU has one of the better work cultures I've ever been a part of.  Lots of dynamic, intelligent people.    

Free EcoPass to all employees.  This is great for me as I live pretty far from campus.  It really saves on my commuting stress-level. 

A week off paid during the holidays!  You gotta love working in education.
cons: What really keeps DU from being a 5-star organization is the pay.  It is painfully low.  The Denver Area is getting more and more expensive, but the rate of pay here has not kept up with the cost of living, nor has it kept up with the market.  There are many, many job opportunities out here with much more competitive salaries, particularly in private industry. There are plenty of options out here for those who don't feel like they're getting fairly compensated. DU will have to address this if they want to retain their employees.

review_title: “A camel is a horse designed by a committee." I hope you like camels.
pros: I'm sure there are good departments to work for at the University of Denver, but the division I was in was not one of them.
cons:
The design request process was essentially nonexistent (an email does not count as a GDR.) The revision process was a nightmare (I'm talking V27 kind of nightmare) and the requested changes were always arbitrary. I would try to explain the reasoning behind my design choices but was quickly dismissed. Management claims they wanted to "push the brand" but every attempt to do so was met with opposition and never approved. If you are a good designer you do not want to work here. All you do is execute other people's, often bad, ideas. You are, effectively, a conduit between management and design programs they don't know how to use. They do not value creatives and do not know how to work with them. 

Also, the culture is toxic and there is virtually no work life balance.

review_title: Collaborative, and supportive environment for research and learning.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: The collaborative atmosphere encourages support at every level and creates the opportunity for a lot of interdisciplinary work. I was given the opportunity to work with my advisor as well as other faculty members. There were also opportunities for employment in other labs for contract work. I used my programming background to earn extra money in the department as well as form collaborations with other faculty that were not in my area.
cons: It is a a small department with limited resources so if there is a new methodology or tool you'd like to use, you'll likely have to go outside the department to gain experience. Reimbursement for conference travel is provided to all students who present there work but the department only covers a portion of travel.

pros: The tuition waiver was a great benefit , free Light Rail pass and laid back work environment were the pluses.
cons:
Lack of communication across the department seems to be a common theme.  Rather than taking the mentality of working together to accomplish goals it is more of the "me" mentality and how can I benefit from this, which leads to a culture of bullying, including senior staff.  Some people are friendly, but not many unless they need something from you.

Senior staff is not in tune with their employees and what is needed to be successful.  They are mainly worried about how something is done so it doesn't make them look bad.  Overall, I would say the senior staff is lacking leadership.  Fed false promises of change.  Constantly missing meetings or not communicating about things.  Most of the staff that actually are doing the work are underpaid.

review_title: Wonderful Students, Delightful Students, Apathetic Faculty
pros: Physical environment is wonderful, wonderful students, terrific library,

The University as a whole is a great environment - it's exciting to work on a college campus. With a new Chancellor I hope to see a new strategic plan for the university that includes an emphasis on quality academic programs, including graduate programs. 

We do enjoy a great work life balance as DU employees with good benefits, decently flexible schedules, etc. I enjoy many of my colleagues and being involved with various groups on campus including Staff Advisory Council and Women's Leadership groups.
cons: Salary is sub-par in comparison to other Universities. We often lose really great people to other Universities who have higher salaries. There is often no room for advancement or there is too much of a political game to gain a promotion. We sometimes feel very top heavy in management with fewer qualified people to do the work necessary to make this a great university. It saddens me when dedicated people are overlooked for positions or not given opportunities to grow professionally.

review_title: Great benefits, however low pay for many admin jobs
pros: Great tuition waiver program, great people to work for. I worked at DU for over 8 years, and I felt like I was part of the community. I was able to get an advanced degree at night and pay little for it because of the awesome tuition waiver program. That is the best thing.
cons: It is hard to be promoted from within. In order for staff to move up they have to transfer departments, as there is little promotion opportunity from within the same department. The pay is low, but the benefits are awesome.

review_title: Focused on the right things - the students and their growth.
job_title: Adjunct Professor, University College in Denver, CO
pros:
Working for University College - the program providing Master's degrees for professionals - is fantastic.  The academic directors appreciate your background, your individual approach to teaching and give you freedom to teach your class your own way, as long as the class objectives are met.  Unlike some for-profit schools at which I've taught, the syllabus and course outlines were there to guide the results of the class, not to remove my ability to be creative and use my skills.  I really appreciated that. 

I felt valued and supported for each class I taught.  I also liked that other professors were generous in their support of each other, despite the fact that there is a little "competition" to teach some classes.
cons: Sometimes I felt a little too "independent" in the classroom, but I suppose if I needed more support I could ask for help.

review_title: Meh...low pay, bad benefits but great people
pros: The office that I worked in was fantastic. They cared about the students, especially management. During the period that I worked there I went through a lot of medical issues. The management and my colleagues were very understanding and helpful.
cons: Health insurance is Kaiser Permanente. It is VERY bad. I had to leave my position due to the misdiagnosis that I received from them. Pay is extremely low. Salary is not commensurate with cost of living in Denver. You have to pay for parking. No free gym access, but DU says it cares about employees' health.

pros: They're all about diversity; they strive to get the best faculty; they offer good scholarships & financial aid to students.  Great benefits for employees!  Staff salary is mediocre.  Beautiful campus!  Ratings below are from a staff member at the bottom of the totem pole.   I'm sure faculty would submit a more positive rating.
cons: I believe staff suffers (because of faculty salaries, and student scholarships).  In my department, we were extremely short-staffed.  We were always putting out fires instead of planning ahead to get processes working right.  I did the job of 2+ assistants, without extra compensation, and was not allowed to work overtime.

pros:
Great supervisors with a vast knowledge of experience who will go to bat for you no matter what when applying/interviewing for other jobs.
Great city to explore and become acquainted with.
Cool work environment (my office was a press box).
Very nice coaches who are easy to work with.
cons: Athletic department administrators allowed an incompetent employee in external relations to make drastic changes to media relations under their watch in April/May 2014, which caused at least four great people including my supervisors to either get demoted or be forced out. The shady behavior of this employee eventually caused his dismissal early last year, but the damage had already been done.

pros: Benefits, work schedule and co-workers. The Campus is beautiful and the work/life balance that is offered is great. The benefits offered balance the low pay.
cons: Pay is below national average. It seems the department heads are incompetent and only the incompetent get promoted. The people on the bottom of the totem pole, not making the money upper management is while working hard to get the job done correctly do not get acknowledged for the achievements. in fact, the more ambition and knowledge you show, it seems the more you are seen as a threat.

review_title: Great benefits, not too demanding, 7.5 hour days

can attend music events at the Performing Arts Center.
cons: There is often quid pro quo on benefits. I was denied my tuition waiver after I rejected my boss's advances. A man was forced out after he took FMLA twice for child birth, DU said he was milking his benefits even though they approved his FMLA. DU only likes young white men.

pros: Great benefits including RTD Eco Pass, tuition benefit, retirement plan, great location, and paid holiday last week of December.

job_title: Library Assistant III in Denver, CO
pros: If you are lucky enough to work in one of the smaller departments with a healthy work environment, you will get to work with some amazing people. There are many faculty members on campus who are exceptionally intelligent and kind, and the campus setting is beautiful. The benefits package is okay.
cons: The administrative bureaucracy is horribly ineffective and inefficient. Furthermore, the compensation structure is abysmal, and most staff are not paid equitable salaries. I work full-time in a position that is not entry-level and that requires AT MINIMUM a bachelor's degree and previous work experience. Yet, two-weeks' pay cannot even cover one month's rent on a tiny, somewhat run-down studio apartment.

pros:
Free room & board for being a Resident Assistant (RA)
Live on campus so you have easy access to your classes
My coworkers (the other RAs) were awesome, we were like a family
cons:
They don't treat you like a person
They preach "self care" but the minute you show signs of struggling they're ready to replace you instantly
You'll have to call the cops and work all-nighters on school nights
You have to work 6 hours at the desk, unpaid
Management will say they're on your side but they're really not, they'll turn on you in an instant
They hire for tokenism to appear to be diverse, not really taking into account capability to accomplish the job. I'm all for diversity and inclusion, but I know some amazing people who would have made amazing RAs and weren't able to get the job because they weren't a token minority.

pros: It is easy to apply for a job through jobs @DU. You can also see where you are in the process through the candidate portal. The interview process was positive, and working at DU has been great over the last seven years. The benefits are comparable to other higher education institutions in the area. Under new leadership, I am noticing an increase in transparent decision-making and changes in the overall culture. The move towards building the community to work to achieve strategic goals together is motivating. The professional development opportunities have always been above and beyond the typical higher education institution.
cons: The process may take longer than expected if you are coming from outside Colorado due to background checks and other employment verification.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University of Denver, CO
pros: Pay is adequate, benefits are good. Campus life is fun and enjoyable. Colorado is a fantastic state. It has everything from professional sports to outdoor activities to thousands of microbreweries. It is difficult to focus on research when there are so many distractions.
cons: Your work and the amount of fulfillment you get from your work is greatly dependent upon your adviser. If your adviser is lax, then you might have a nice work/life balance, but will not be able to be productive with your research. On the other hand, if your adviser pushes you, you will likely succeed professionally, but you likely will not be able to maintain your non-work life.

review_title: Pardee Center for International Futures @ DU: Proceed with caution
pros: The staff of this research center are exceptionally intelligent, hardworking, and collaborative people. The work itself is interesting and can be impactful. Beautiful campus and some nice benefits.
cons: Leadership is unprofessional and challenging.  No support from the University's HR, despite regular outreach from staff trying to maker the situation better. Micromanaging, lack of trust, and accusatory language from senior leadership prevent people from doing their jobs well. No support for professional development; in fact, staff are routinely set up for failure. Despite a strong team with a variety of valuable skills, people are often tasked with projects outside their expertise areas and discouraged from collaborating. Senior leadership creates a culture of gossip, back-biting, and personal insults. High turnover. Many leave without another position, just to escape a toxic environment.

job_title: Resident Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The directors of HRE are very considerate towards a student's priorities and they are adaptable to student scheduling.  The compensation of room and board is an outstanding deal, considering that the job works well to any student's schedule.
cons: In many cases, RAs must go above and beyond the job description to make sure incidents that do not follow the honor code are properly addressed.  This can require later nights and extra commitments than originally thought.

pros: There are no pros.  The place is micro-managed by people or committees that should NOT be involved in decisions.
cons:
VP's and Directors are dinosaurs, are incompetent, and micro-manage.  The place is a degree factory who cares nothing about being innovative or the students.  Unqualified committees rule the place; thus nothing gets done.
There is no progressive discipline policy (weak HR), so I have witnessed others be fired for nothing; there is no recourse because there is no discipline policy (the way the university cowardly protects itself).   
Horrible place to work..due to no one having balls to get things done, innovate, or let the people who KNOW their job DO their job (micro-management).

review_title: Great place to work if you are looking to advance your education...

cons: Compensation is well below peers

review_title: This is a review for the Pardee Center based at the University of Denver
pros:
1. Amazing and unique work
2. A great combination of a think tank and an academic institution
3. The founder of the Center is one of the most passionate and thoughtful voices in the field of Integrated Assessment Modeling (IAM). He is a great mentor and a delight to work with.
4. Opportunities to work with clients like the UN  and USAID on the world's most pressing questions related to development policy.
5. Denver is a great city to live and work
6. Opportunities to work with amazing graduate and undergraduate level research assistants who go to school at DU. 
7. Some of the smartest individuals I have had the opportunity to work with in my career.
8. Decent benefits.
cons:
1. Upper management (other than the founder) is too dysfunctional .
2. High levels of micro-management and gas lighting.
3. If you are an international student who requires any kind of visa sponsorship, please do not consider working here. Your visa requirements will be treated as a vulnerability in every review meeting.
4. The upper management (excluding the founder) is too insecure and projects are assigned on the basis of favoritism.
5. Imaginary deadlines are set which employees strive hard to meet. This leads to unnecessary and unhealthy levels of stress and over work. 
6. Very low employee morale and high employee turnover.
7.  The management needs to be conscious of how it treats women and minorities in the work place (especially  in terms of project assignment and reviews). (PS- I would advise you to call Korbel HR before accepting a job here and asking about complaints against the Pardee Center)
 8. Review meetings are treated more as a form of a way to target your shortcomings as an individual rather than reviewing actual work.   
9. The upper management (once again, excluding the founder)  gets insecure when you are good at your job and show any kind of promise as an employee.

job_title: Office of Admission in Denver, CO
pros:
The university energy is contagious! 
There are great opportunities to pursue education and develop professionally.
Great opportunity to expand network. 
Great hours and flexibility.
Great matching with 401K.

Overall the employees feel valued and that they are contributing to the  future of the university. It's great to be able to work directly with students. The type of work is going to vary day-to-day and go by "cycles" due to recruitment. The atmosphere is exciting and your colleagues are intelligent, caring and fun individuals to be around.
cons:
Low starting pay.
Very strict organizational structure.

pros: Great benefits.  The best flexibility.  Good place to work if you have kids.  Very interesting environment - in a positive intellectual way.  Diverse work colleagues.  Community feeling.
cons: The pay is low.  Lots of red tape required to change things.

review_title: Paid extremely low and no direction from higher up
job_title: PASS Camp Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: My job entailed working with kids, which can be rewarding. The facilities at DU are amazing, and getting access to them during my employment was great.
cons: Higher up doesn't back up the staff. Ridiculous considerations like not allowing you to have coffee in the morning while on the clock. Pay is awful for what they expect you to do. Blame everything on you rather than trying to figure out the problem, makes a bad work environment when it's lower staff vs. higher staff.

review_title: Great team with a great boss.
pros: I work for intramurals at the University of Denver. It's so much fun to work with friends and get paid to do something I love. The higher ups are always willing to work with you as far as hours go, they know we're students first. They also let you play on a team if you want to. You don't have to have work study to work for intramurals.
cons: Kind of hard to move up. Only a few supervisor roles available, and they're usually filled until the person graduates or quits.

pros: Some really talented and dedicated staff. A beautiful environment to work. Good benefits and leave policies. Good work/life balance
cons: Salaries are way below national standards compared to other Higher Education institutions. The place is very highly political and run by a small network of insiders. They give lip service to getting employee input but they generally ignore it. Three to four people hold all the power and make all the decisions. Even higher level administrators seem powerless.

pros:
Lots of freedom for faculty
Nice buildings
cons: The University espouses ethics as one of its strengths, yet I have never worked at a more unethical place.  Employees are not given straight feedback.  Instead, managers make their lives miserable, trumped up complaints are filed, and good people are pushed out.  If you threaten the folks at the top, they will get rid of you.

review_title: A private school with a good education, if you can afford it
pros: Smaller classes make it easier to have in depth learning and lots of one on one time with professors.
cons: The cost is extremely prohibitive if you do not have a scholarship or a means to pay for the high tuition bill.

pros: Health benefits through Kaiser are fantasitc; 401k matching is awesome! The staff who work at DU truly care about the students and the campus community.
cons: PAY for staff (note: I don't know about faculty pay).Very low compared to the cost of living in Denver and when you consider what families pay for tuition at this school. They are working on improving this, but it is a loooooong process that few can afford to stick around for.

pros: Since the institution has been around for so long, they are able to offer quite a bit of support and have an incredible benefits program. Lots of departments creating lots of opportunities to transfer laterally or for other various growth opportunities. Large group of the staff has been there for quite a while proving employee retention is strong.
cons: Because the institution is quite old, there are ways, some more obvious than others, in which they are pretty old-fashioned.

review_title: Assistant Director of Gifts and Records
job_title: Assistant Director of Gifts and Records in Denver, CO
pros: A very capable staff to work along side.  Reasonable work hours, great benefits, and located in an incredible part of Denver.
cons: Relatively low pay and a very specific culture.  Aside from the processing staff, most development professionals at the University were very much alike.  Not a great deal of diversity in terms of personalities.

pros:
The school is in the most perfect location, close to down town and the mountains, but far enough away that you feel like you are part of a smaller community. 
I loved basically every professor and the campus is gorgeous.
cons: I wish they would have had a football team, having big events like that are fun. Hockey and lacrosse don't quite fill that void. There are also a lot of students from very wealthy families which can make for a "stuck up/snobby" atmosphere at times.

job_title: Banquet Event Staff in Denver, CO
pros: They were very willing to work around my class schedule, give time off for finals, and give me flexible hours that could change week to week
cons: There were some very early morning and very late night shifts, shifts can sometimes run late (though they were good about letting people who had to get to class leave on time), pay wasn't great

job_title: Psychology Department Research Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: Hands on work experience in a research lab
cons:
Low standards by supervisors that did not celebrate those who accomplished more as research assistants than others - ultimately, it created an environment in which laziness was beneficial as you would simply do less work, and those who worked harder had nothing to show for it. 
Shady lab practices asking research assistants to apply for grants offered to support independent undergraduate work, only to be used on projects the supervisors were conducting.

pros: Work life balance, tuition reimbursement, co-workers, location- The Univesrity has a wonderful enviornment and is a plesant place to work every day. There are many benefits outside of the job that employees can enjoy.
cons: Poor compensation, decentralized, poor communication-  There is a large gap between faculty and staff compensation. This has been noted by the university, however cuts continue to occur, and pay raises are merit only, not cost of living raises.

pros: Great tuition benefits, nice community of colleagues, work/life balance is good, casual dress code (depends on department)
cons: Very low wages for industry, no upward growth opportunities, too much responsibility with no rewards (no title changes or bonuses). Merit increases are barely cost of living increases. Takes years for processes to change, lots of red tape. Not a lot of transparency.

job_title: Marketing and Communications in Denver, CO
pros: Some really great people who try really hard to fight the good fight and make a difference. Really flexible work/life balance and great benefits.
cons: A place where medicroty is allowed to flourish and innovation is discouraged. Extremely political. Openly encourages a hostile work environment. One of the most unprofessional, misguided, short sighted, myopic places I've worked. Total lack of diversity and accountability. Good workers and top talent are actively forced out.

pros: Small community feeling. I feel that I am treated with respect. The benefits package is better than anywhere I have worked. Get along with everyone.
cons: I really have no complaints about the job itself, I only wish there were more room to grow and advance. Pay could be better.

pros: Good work life balance, great benefits, beautiful campus.
cons: Upper level administration is dishonest, one day we're told the university is in great shape, the next there are mass layoffs, little room for advancement, pay is low, annual raises do not account for cost of living increases, looked down upon for taking earned sick/vacation time.

pros: DU offers decent benefits.  Tuition benefit is fantastic.  The university is family friendly and offers a lot of flexibility. The people are very friendly and I worked in several departments with really great staff.
cons: The growth opportunities are limited and the culture is not always great to internal candidates. Often this is because the internal candidates don't have the same experience as externals.  The University is very decentralized and the culture/pay, etc. can be very different between departments/colleges.

review_title: Decent place to work, especially for folks who want to complete a grad. or PhD program
pros: Tuition waiver, access to University lectures, professional development, wellness program, decent benefits and time off,
cons: bureaucratic processes, admin.'s in various dept.'s at both College and University levels are very siloed

pros: Their tuition waiver policy starts within 6 months of full-time employment.  Their HR dept also has numerous programs geared towards professional development.
cons: They cater to mediocrity in their employees. Their departments (Registrar,  Campus Life, Financial Aid, etc) struggle to find talent capable of making any real impact.  There's a reason they can't compete with USC,  Notre Dame, etc.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Denver, CO
pros: Beautiful campus, terrific staff, lots of potential.
cons: Slow to deal with problem employees, managers don't know how to manage.  Very supportive environment at the peer level, not at all supportive hierarchy.

pros: The benefits are good: good health plan, good PTO and sick leave, depending on unit there is the opportunity for flexibility.
cons: Salaries are low and raises are low.  Workplace environment is variable and really depends on the unit.  Some units really value staff while others do not.  Its important to really check out the unit you might work in for good fit.

pros: Great opportunity for students looking to make a little extra money while enrolled.  The staff is great and the work environment is superb.  Everyone is passionate about their languages and are super fun.
cons: Not much room for advancement.  But then again, this is a part-time job for students.

pros: Very flexible hours, fun job, great staff to work with.  You get to choose your own hours based on your school schedule but still can make quite a bit of money by picking up the shifts of others.  The team is great and the job itself is really fun.
cons: The only major con I can think of is the fact that, depending on your schedule, you can some quarters only give tours on Fridays.

review_title: A prestigious university with a culture of inclusiveness, global perspective and ethical practice.
pros: Benefits include the richness of an academic community, affordable health coverage, a 401K and education support.
cons: Downsides include compensation level, opportunity for advancement (a flat organizational structure), and a culture where things happen ‘slowly and by committee’.

pros: Great place to work, nice campus, benefits aren't terrible, people are friendly, and there is flexibility in the work.
cons: My biggest complaint with DU is the pay. It's a place I would love to grow but with the pay being so low it makes it hard to value yourself as an important employee when the pay is next to nothing.

review_title: Review for Frederick Pardee Center for International Futures - Toxic work environment
pros:
- Interesting and challenging work in international development and security.
- Opportunity to work with large international organizations like USAID and the UN.
- Staff and graduate research assistants are generally brilliant, kind people who are passionate about research.
- Ability to work in the international relations/development field in Denver is a huge benefit.
- Opportunity use and learn the International Futures modelling platform with the creator of platform and founder of the center.
- Pay for staff is pretty good for the international relations/development field.
cons:
- Senior management manipulates and demeans employees on a regular basis. Narcissistic and controlling behavior is the norm.
- Senior management discourages teamwork, collaboration, and professional growth beyond its immediate purview. 
- Senior management bullies and/or gas-lights staff into believing their work is mundane, replaceable, and/or downright terrible. Condescension and put-downs are pervasive.
- Senior management wavers between extreme micromanagement of personnel and projects and compete neglect of organizational management duties.
- Senior management is profoundly unprofessional. Interactions are often riddled with inappropriate comments and feedback often turns personal.
- The on-boarding process was nearly non-existent - I didn't know who my HR representative was or where to report issues. I was discouraged from expressing issues with management through proper channels.

pros: A potential chance to work with clients like USAID, the UN, and the African Union. Experience learning data analysis and quantitative modeling. Opportunities to travel and work overseas with development practitioners. Intelligent and passionate coworkers with a desire to learn, grow, and be of service. A chance to work with and mentor students (grad and undergrad). Excellent benefits. The founder of the Pardee Center and the IFs model is an amazing man and a great mentor.
cons:
Despite all of the pros listed above, the Pardee Center for International Futures at the Josef Korbel School of International Studies at the University of Denver can only be described as a toxic workplace with pervasive bullying.

I worked at the center for 2 years as a grad student and then several years full-time after I graduated. I watched as employee after employee quit, usually completely frustrated with the work environment, often in tears, sometimes claiming emotional abuse. I watched as my coworkers were intimidated and bullied until they reached the end of their ropes and left. When I raised these concerns, senior management became defensive and nothing was done. Once I realized that senior management is unable or unwilling to change, I left too. I told HR (both Korbel and DU) all of this in my exit interview, and I know several other current and former employees have made official complaints about this as well, and DU has done nothing as far as I know.

If you work here you will be made to feel small and stupid. Senior management will use a combination of intimidation, gaslighting, and division to maintain fear and control. You will be ignored for a while and then your work will be criticized without any evidence. Every workplace has issues, but I’ve been working elsewhere for a while now and the longer I am away from the Pardee Center the more I realize how toxic it was. 

There are a lot of great people that work here and the benefits are great, but that’s no substitute for your peace of mind and emotional well-being. If you work here part time as a student, you’ll probably be fine but don’t stay for too long after that.

review_title: This place is your worst nightmare and you should avoid it at all costs (IT Division).
pros: Free education, matching 8% retirement, pretty campus.
cons:
Thinking of applying for a job at DU? Allow me to shed some light on how this soul sucking entity operates. I worked in their IT division for quite some time. Saw a lot of changes over the years, but nothing prepared us for the Reckoning when their current Vice Chancellor & CIO took over. He advocated and created a culture of blame and authoritarianism parallel to what is currently happening in the Trump Administration. Experienced senior leadership that was in place for years were removed or ousted in favor of managers that had literally zero experience in their respective departments. This current leadership follows by example and continues to hire and promote those who only show one quality: blind fanaticism and unquestionable loyalty. Anyone else with actual intelligence or experience were frequently passed over for promotions. If any employee questions any process or decision, they are immediately flagged by management as a danger to their system of control. Many of these employees were systematically targeted by management and performed down in annual reviews, perpetually harassed, gaslit, and constantly attacked by lies of underperformance, attitude, or performance issues. Many talented employees have already quit and the rest that remain live in a constant state of fear and low morale. Every month more employees put in their resignation letters like rats off a sinking ship. New hires do not last very long and turnover is very high. Many existing employees are on anti-depressants or anti-anxiety medications due to the severe hostile work environment. Critical infrastructure and support is on the verge of catastrophic failure, all due to management’s lack of experience and negligence to take the advice of their engineers seriously. Its a House of Cards. Enterprise standards are laughed at and decisions are seemingly made by throwing darts at a board. Management doesn’t want to take the time to understand or learn the technicals behind their own environment they manage so as to make better decisions. They only want results and then blame their engineers, developers or support specialists when things go off the rails. They own zero accountability. Some managers scream at their subordinates, others publicly ridicule them in front of others. Still yet the ones who appear to be nice and understanding simply lie to your face to placate you. Some of the worst managers are so controlling, they act like it’s the military and micromanage every facet of your role, leaving out any delegation or decision making. Processes are burdened by a complete lack of communication back from management and approvals from them seemingly never get approved due to this. The backlash from employees have been in the form of a stack of HR complaints and employee separation interviews. Worst part is that HR has acknowledged they are not willing to step in and make any real changes, despite the volume of real, proven, and collaborated evidence showcasing a clear hostile work environment. 

This place is your worst nightmare and you should avoid it at all costs.

job_title: Strategic Research Consultant in Washington, DC
pros: The work is really interesting and has real world impact. The staff are made up of dedicated and intelligent people.
cons: There is no vision or guidance given for projects. Project management is lacking and there are not clear products, goals, or even thesis questions to the majority of projects. This is not only frustrating but sets employees up for chronic failure.

pros: DU is a beautiful university with kind staff. A good place to work- benefits for full-time employees include tuition credit. DU also has fun opportunities for staff, like cooking classes in the hospitality school.
cons: Part-time employees may feel undervalued in comparison to full-time employees as they are not eligible for many of the benefits including gym discounts.

pros: Holiday vacation from Christmas eve until new years, classes are free after 6 months of working here
cons: Pay is terrible, climate is really rigid, things don't change, white men run this place, there are no mid level to high level jobs unless you know the white men in leadership, DU doesn't actually care about their employees

review_title: Student Affairs-- A beautiful working environment with lots of great co workers.
pros:
--Lovely campus
--Always interesting things going on 
--Support Work Life Balance
--Excellent Benefits
--Nice and smart co-workers
--A lot of people feel passionate about assisting students
--Support for new ideas
cons:
--Pay is extremely low
--For some positions not many places to move up to and increase earning potential

pros: The university is a great community of people. They have excellent benefits and are very flexible. As a full-time working mom and wife flexibility it critical to our family and I found it at DU. They have a tuition waiver program for benefited employees and their children/spouses.
cons: Pay is lower then standard industry. They lead with the extra benefits, flexibility, tuition waivers etc. to try and make up for that.

pros: I frequently can do homework during down-time in my position if there is nothing to do.  My boss is very understanding of the fact that I am a student as well.
cons: After having the same job again this year I had to get "re-hired" and go through a background check processing again, but really it only took a few days and wasn't bad.  Just something they do by protocol I guess.

review_title: Oh, if only I could rate DU with less than 1 star
job_title: Marketing and Communications in Denver, CO
pros: Talented front line people; great organizational mission/vision; proximity to light rail and DU provides free light rail pass.
cons: While people on the front lines are talented (I loved everyone I worked with directly), most of those in senior leadership positions (Vice Chancellors and above) could best be described as inhuman. Don't be suckered into letting anyone tell you that DU has a positive culture or that you will have a positive work-life balance. It may seem that way on the surface, but go to work for them and within 6 months you'll be wishing you hadn't turned down that job working for Donald Trump. The culture is one of entitlement, racism, sexism, ageism, and it's all around unhealthy. Leaders do not care about the physical or mental health of their employees and in fact, in many cases, I have personally witnessed (and experienced) senior "leaders" mentally abusing employees to the point of breakdown, and when you report the behavior to HR or the EEOC/Title IX offices, you are outright ignored. On top of all this, you are expected to work ridiculously long hours, to be on call at all times of the day (including weekends and holidays) and the pay is abysmal, verging on embarrassing. I got out as fast as I could!

pros:
Tuition waiver & other benefits
Centrally located, pretty campus
Events and ways to get involved
Good work-life balance in most departments
You can learn a lot, if you want to
cons:
Low pay & no opportunities for advancement
Decentralized, & poor communication / coordination among units (there are some efforts to fix this with the new strategic plan)
No incentives to do your best, can get very boring
Don't expect to be compensated well

review_title: Great benefits, good environment and co-workers, though every one is overworked.
pros: Amazing staff in my department, dedication to student wellbeing, tangible attempts to improve diversity and inclusive culture, and great benefits.
cons: Though the student tuition is high (too high), the faculty and staff are not paid as a reflection of this. Lacking in some transparency for situations like this one.

review_title: An incredibly supportive community that cares about personal development and organizational achievement.
pros: The people! I love my colleagues and being in a university atmosphere. The benefits of educational advancement are unmatched. The exposure to networks, building social capital and being happy at work are invaluable. Vacation, flex, sick days, personal time...
cons: Salaries in education in general are underpaid

review_title: Spent 10yrs of my life happily giving to the University, never a return in the time spent.......
pros: Great if you are student who can survive on next to nothing. Your benefits will help you get your degree, but that's what they use to justify the low pay. You can look forward to having the same job you were hired for when you finally decide to leave.
cons: Low, uncompetitive wages - NO chance for advancement - will not promote from within - job training is N/A - Leadership is nepotistic - Change never happens - internal issues are political and never get resolved - no form of metrics or hard data to measurement performance, performance is based on peer popularity or how well management 'likes' you.  Time off for anything is a hassle of red tape and management forgets requests, even medical leave, which is shameful. You will find no work-life balance here, you will find no cost of living adjustments to your salary, you will suffer by taking any position here.

job_title: Athletics and Recreation in Denver, CO
pros:
Good Benefits
Tuition Waiver 
Different learning opportunities 
Discounts from local vendors
Employee Events around Campus
cons:
Due to being affiliated with the University of Denver, many opportunities are let go that would bring more people on to the campus
Sometimes feels like a dictatorship with the hierarchy levels

review_title: Small, but prestigious school. A lot of money flows through DU.
pros: Great Business and Law Schools. Job opportunities after graduation. You can meet a lot of people with strong connections in the business community. Good alumni network and career services.
cons: EXPENSIVE (upwards of $50,000 a year without financial aid). Very small campus. Does not have the same school pride and collegiate feel of some major state universities.

review_title: Great experience for students or great stepping stone opportunities to the "real world"
pros: Depends on the department you work in, but working on campus is convenient to a student schedule. Usually the hours are flexible enough to not fall behind in class work.
cons: Working within the politics of a private university can be very restricting and difficult. You have to account for politics when implementing project.

job_title: Graduate Teachers Assistant in Denver, CO

cons: While the research is fulfilling, due to the time it takes to publish research papers, some of the research work done can't be seen through to fruition.

job_title: Student Services in University of Denver, CO

cons: Graduate enrollments are down, so administration is pushing hard for higher head counts. Not backing it up with additional scholarship funds, though, which is what prospective students need because of high tuition.

pros: A laid-back work atmosphere that allows you to grow at your own pace while ensuring that you do grow. The pay isn't half bad, considering the other benefits gained.
cons: You sometimes have to question whether the top echelons really have it all together. There are times where they should respond and fail to because they are too occupied with something much less important.

pros:
There are many inspiring people, especially in the new Engineering and Computer Science building. It's easy to find a group of people to collaborate with.

I was paid via the federally funded work-study program, so I can't speak to salaries, benefits, ect.
cons: Funding is rather poorly distributed. Not enough goes back into the students, much of it is funneled into events for investors/alumni.

review_title: I wouldn't recommend DU for a workplace

cons: I seemed to have stumbled upon more politics here than other institutions of higher ed, and even the best people at DU suffered because of it.

review_title: Management changes have significantly impacted job satisfaction. Some managers are promoted that shouldn't be.

Impressive and inspirational faculty.
Work, life balance.
Excellent benefits.

Lack of professionalism missing in some departments.
Some management lack good management skills. (Tend to "manage" not "lead" or "empower". Specifically middle management.)

job_title: Director of Student Conduct in Denver, CO

review_title: Good place to work when you are a student.

review_title: A good place with penny-wise dollar-dumb leadership

pros: Team culture, open-minded culture, school reputation, good benefits, beautiful campus

job_title: Human Resources Professional in Denver, CO
